title: The no-bs blueprint
description: The video provides a no-nonsense blueprint for high school students with real ambition to get into T20 and Ivy League institutions. It emphasizes the importance of starting early and choosing a career path to build a strong application. The video aims to provide helpful advice for those who are serious about their future.

title: Picking a Career Path Early (How & Why)
description: Picking a career path early is important because it allows you to actively pursue different fields and understand what you like. By doing so, you can build a resume and position yourself for Ivy League applications. Even if you change your mind later on, the work you've done is not wasted and can still be marketed towards your new interests. It's better to start thinking about your career path early on because it becomes harder to change later in life. When it comes to clubs, it's better to pick a small number and commit to them fully.

title: Getting involved in clubs (the best way)
description: Get involved in clubs that align with your career goals and have opportunities for competition. Winning competitions can boost your self-confidence and set you up for success later in life. Consider whether sports are worth the time commitment and explore other ways to get exercise. There are other ways to boost your resume beyond clubs, which will be discussed later.

title: The BEST Extracurriculars for 9th/10th graders
description: The video suggests that 9th/10th graders should get involved in shadowing, internships, and volunteering to build their resume and gain exposure to different fields. Shadowing for 60-80 hours, interning during the summer, and volunteering in the community are all great ways to start building a foundation for future success.

title: SECURING THE BAG (~10th Grade)
description: Sophomore year is a pivotal time to get involved in clubs and take on leadership roles. It's also a good time to build up extracurriculars before junior year gets too busy. This is the time to compete in science fairs and start prepping for standardized exams.

title: SAT/ACT Prep Schedule
description: Start SAT/ACT prep in fall of sophomore year, practice regularly, choose an exam date (August of sophomore year is recommended), study hard during the summer before the exam, aim for a high score (at least 1500 for SAT, 34+ for ACT).

title: Making a Truly Unique Application
description: The video discusses how to create a unique application for college. The speaker suggests focusing on academics and extracurricular activities in sophomore year, with room for a secondary priority. They recommend using the summer to work on a special extracurricular, such as a nonprofit, to stand out. Junior year is focused on maintaining leadership positions in chosen clubs and excelling in academics.

title: Optimal Junior Year Shenanigans
description: Focus on top extracurriculars and prioritize schoolwork in junior year. Start thinking about college admissions in second semester of junior year and begin researching schools and writing essays early.

title: COLLEGE APPS TIME (with bonus tip)
description: Start college applications in second semester of junior year, focus on personal statement and supplemental essays during summer. Try to minimize internship work during junior year summer to focus on essays. Finish submitting applications by end of summer to reduce stress during senior year. Keep up with clubs and leadership positions during senior year. Finish strong academically and enjoy second semester of senior year. Create a blueprint for high school goals and tasks, and follow it consistently. Trust the process and put in the work for Ivy League admission.
